newsitem.title: THAILAND: Central bank backs Finance One, Thai Danu merger.
newsitem.headline: Central bank backs Finance One, Thai Danu merger.

text.p: Bank of Thailand governor Rerngchai Marakanond said on Saturday the central bank agreed with the planned merger between Finance One Plc and Thai Danu Bank Plc.
"I have been informed verbally of Finance One and Thai Danu merger and I am waiting to hear their final agreement," Rerngchai told reporters.
"I personally agree with the move which is basically a normal commercial merger designed for strengthening their business and efficiency as well as for trimming their expenses," the governor said.
He was in Phuket attending a one-day meeting of finance ministers from the seven-member Association of South East Asian Nations.
Earlier on Saturday, finance ministry sources and local newspapers said Finance One and medium-sized Thai Danu had agreed to merge. Finance One is Thailand's largest finance company.
Details of the proposed merger, the biggest shake-up in the domestic financial sector in more than a decade, would likely be announced on Monday and take time to be completed, they added.
Rerngchai also dismissed speculation that Finance One faced financial problems, which some analysts say has prompted it to merge with Thai Danu.

"We must distinguish the fact that Finance One has not faced any problems, although maybe some of its affiliates may have some short-term liquidity problems which have been taken care of by the central bank," Rerngchai said.
Earlier this week, rumours circulated that Finance One had faced a run on deposits from major clients and has had to pay high premiums to secure funds.
The company denied the rumours on Friday.
Suspicions about Finance One's health triggered heavy selloff of finance stocks this past week and helped pull down the overall market, brokers said.
